questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with hyperthermia, tachycardia, and altered mental status following an abrupt discontinuation of her antithyroid medication. Upon examination, she is diaphoretic, has a goitre, and exhibits hand tremors. Which of the following is the DOC for managing her condition?

options.label: B
options.text: Administer a large dose of Propylthiouracil

questions.correct_answer: B. Administer a large dose of Propylthiouracil
questions.explanation:
Thyroid Storm

Clinical Features
  • Fever with diaphoresis.
  • Cardiovascular Involvement: Tachycardia (>140 bpm), heart failure, arrhythmias, hypotension, and risk of cardiac arrest.
  • CNS Manifestations: Agitation, delirium, anxiety, psychosis, or coma.
  • Gastrointestinal Symptoms: Nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea, abdominal pain, intestinal obstruction, and acute hepatic failure.

Management
  • Initial Supportive Measures: IV fluids, oxygen, cooling blankets, and acetaminophen.
  • Beta-blocker Therapy: Start with propranolol immediately (40-80 mg every 4-6 hours) to control adrenergic tone.
  • DOC: Administer propylthiouracil (500-1000 mg loading, then 250 mg every 4 hours) or methimazole (20 mg every 4-6 hours). 
  • Iodine Solution: Give SSKI (5 drops every 6 hours) after thionamide to reduce the release of thyroid hormone
  • Glucocorticoids: Hydrocortisone (100 mg IV every 8 hours) or dexamethasone (2 mg every 6 hours).
  • Cholestyramine (Bile acid sequestrant): 4 grams orally 4 times daily for severe cases to reduce enterohepatic recycling of thyroid hormone.
  • Surgery: Thyroidectomy for patients with contraindications to thionamides after pre-treatment.
  • Definitive Treatment: Recommend radioiodine therapy or surgery for hyperthyroidism once stabilised.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman is scheduled for thyroidectomy. Her current thyroid function tests show decreased TSH level and elevated free T3 & T4. Which of the following is the most appropriate preoperative management to prevent thyroid storm?

options.label: A
options.text: Start propranolol alone one day before surgery

options.label: B
options.text: Start methimazole and wait for normal thyroid function tests

options.label: C
options.text: Start methimazole, potassium iodide, and propranolol 7-10 days before surgery

options.label: D
options.text: Proceed directly to surgery with close monitoring

questions.correct_answer: C. Start methimazole, potassium iodide, and propranolol 7-10 days before surgery

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with a history of multinodular goitre undergoes a CT angiogram with iodinated contrast for suspected pulmonary embolism. Two weeks later, she presents with palpitations, heat intolerance, and weight loss. Her thyroid function tests show suppressed TSH and elevated T3 and T4. Which of the following best explains this patient's current condition?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Wolff-Chaikoff Effect

Jod-Basedow Effect

Definition

Temporary inhibition of thyroid hormone synthesis in response to high iodine exposure

Iodine-induced hyperthyroidism

Mechanism

High iodine levels inhibit thyroid peroxidase, reducing T3 and T4 production

Excess iodine stimulates autonomous thyroid hormone production in susceptible individuals

Duration

Temporary (usually resolves in 1-2 weeks)

Can persist until treated

Thyroid Function Tests

Initially decreased T3 and T4, increased TSH

Increased T3 and T4, decreased TSH

At-risk Population

Normal thyroid glands

Pre-existing thyroid disease (e.g., multinodular goiter, Graves' disease)

Clinical Presentation

Usually asymptomatic or mild hypothyroid symptoms

Symptoms of hyperthyroidism (e.g., palpitations, heat intolerance, weight loss)

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents with a 2-week history of palpitations, anxiety, and weight loss. On examination, her heart rate is 110 bpm and regular, and she has a painful goitre. Thyroid function tests show decreased TSH level and elevated free T3 & T4 levels. A thyroid scan shows very low uptake. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 35-year-old woman presents with a history of weight loss, palpitations, and heat intolerance. On examination, she has a diffuse goitre, Ophthalmopathy and fine tremors in her outstretched hands. Her thyroid function tests show: TSH: < 0.01 mIU/L (normal range: 0.4-4.0 mIU/L) Free T4: 35 pmol/L (normal range: 10-20 pmol/L) Free T3: 12 pmol/L (normal range: 3.5-6.5 pmol/L) Which of the following is the most likely cause of her hyperthyroidism?
questions.explanation:
Cause

Key Features for identification

Primary Hyperthyroidism (pathology within the thyroid gland)

Graves' disease

Diffuse goitre, ophthalmopathy, TSH receptor antibodies (LATS- long-acting thyroid stimulating antibodies)

Toxic multinodular goiter

Multiple autonomous nodules, older patients

Toxic adenoma

Single autonomous nodule

Subacute thyroiditis (de Quervain thyroiditis)

Painful thyroid, recent viral illness, transient

Silent thyroiditis (Painless lymphocytic thyroiditis)

Painless, often postpartum, transient

Iodine-induced thyrotoxicosis

History of iodine exposure (e.g., contrast, amiodarone)

Drug-induced (e.g., amiodarone)

History of relevant medication use

Secondary Hyperthyroidism

TSH-secreting pituitary adenoma

Inappropriate TSH secretion, other pituitary hormones may be affected

hCG-mediated hyperthyroidism

Pregnancy, gestational trophoblastic disease

(Alpha subunit of hCG is similar in structure to TSH)

Thyroid hormone resistance (rare)

Genetic disorder, reduced sensitivity of the body to thyroid hormone.

Ectopic Hyperthyroidism

Struma ovarii

Ovarian teratoma with functional thyroid tissue

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with complaints of irritability, difficulty sleeping, and unexplained weight loss of 10 kg over the past 3 months despite an increased appetite. His wife mentions that his eyes seem more prominent lately. Which of the following findings would be least likely in this patient?

options.label: C
options.text: Delayed relaxation of deep tendon reflexes

questions.correct_answer: C. Delayed relaxation of deep tendon reflexes
questions.explanation:
System

Signs and Symptoms

General

Weight loss despite increased appetite, Heat intolerance, Increased sweating.

Cardiovascular

Tachycardia, Widened pulse pressure, and Atrial fibrillation

Neurological

Fine tremor, Hyperreflexia, Anxiety, irritability, and Insomnia.

Gastrointestinal

Increased bowel movements, Diarrhoea and Malabsorption.

Dermatological

Warm, moist skin, Fine, thin hair, Onycholysis.

Ocular (Graves' specific)

Exophthalmos, Lid lag, Lid retraction, and Periorbital oedema.

Musculoskeletal

Proximal muscle weakness, Osteoporosis

Reproductive

Oligomenorrhea, Gynecomastia (in men)

Thyroid Storm

High fever, Severe tachycardia/arrhythmias, Delirium/coma, Multi-organ failure

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with fatigue, weight gain, and changes in her skin appearance over the past year. On examination, her skin is noted to be dry with a yellowish tinge. There is puffiness around her eyes and non-pitting edema in hands and feet. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for her skin findings?

A 35-year-old woman weighing 65 Kgs comes with complaints of lethargy and weight gain. Lab investigations are carried out, which show elevated TSH level and Decresed T3 & T4 levels. She has no known cardiovascular disease. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step regarding this patient?

options.label: C
options.text: Start liothyronine (T3) 5 μg three times daily

options.label: D
options.text: Observe and repeat thyroid function tests in 3 months

questions.explanation:
Hypothyroidism- Treatment

Primary Treatment

Levothyroxine (T4) replacement

Initial Dosing

- Young, otherwise healthy adults: 1.6 μg/kg/day (typically 100-150 μg daily) (Option B)

- Elderly or those with cardiovascular disease: Start with 25-50 μg daily and titrate up slowly (Option A ruled out)

- Pregnancy: May require 30-50% dose increase

Dose Adjustments

- Based on TSH levels

- Adjust in 12.5-25 μg increments

- Allow 6-8 weeks between dose changes for TSH to stabilize

Monitoring

- Check TSH 6-8 weeks after starting treatment or changing dose

- Once stable, check TSH annually

- Target TSH: 0.4-4.0 mIU/L for most adults, < 2.5 mIU/L in 1st trimester.

Alternative Treatments

- T3 (liothyronine) alone: Not recommended due to short half-life

- Combination T4/T3 therapy: Controversial, not routinely recommended

questions.text: A 78-year-old woman was brought to the emergency department by her family due to progressive lethargy over the past week. On examination, she is unresponsive with a core temperature of 32°C, BP of 80/50 mmHg, and HR of 40 bpm. Her skin is dry and cool, and she has periorbital edema. Initial lab results show: Sodium: 128 mEq/L (normal 135-145) TSH: 75 mIU/L (normal 0.4-4.0) Free T4: 3 pmol/L (normal 10-20) Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management?

options.label: B
options.text: Intravenous liothyronine 10 μg, followed by 10 μg every 8 hours

options.label: C
options.text: Oral levothyroxine 50 μg daily and oral liothyronine 5 μg twice daily

options.label: D
options.text: Supportive care only and repeat thyroid function tests in 24 hours

questions.correct_answer: B. Intravenous liothyronine 10 μg, followed by 10 μg every 8 hours
questions.explanation:
Myxedema coma

Precipitating Factors

- Infection

- Cold exposure

- Trauma

- Medications (sedatives, anaesthetics)

- Discontinuation of thyroid hormone

Diagnosis

- Clinical presentation

- Elevated TSH, low Free T4

- Associated lab abnormalities (hyponatremia, hypoglycemia, hypercapnia)

Initial Management

1. Intravenous T3 (liothyronine): 10-20 μg bolus, then 10 μg q8h

2. Intravenous levothyroxine: 300-500 μg loading dose

3. Hydrocortisone: 100 mg q8h (for potential adrenal insufficiency)

4. Supportive care: Mechanical ventilation if needed, cautious rewarming, fluid resuscitation with Hypertonic saline

questions.text: A 68-year-old man is admitted to the ICU with severe sepsis secondary to pneumonia. On day 3 of his admission, routine blood tests reveal the following thyroid function results: TSH: 0.6 mIU/L (normal range: 0.4-4.0 mIU/L) Free T4: 12 pmol/L (normal range: 10-20 pmol/L) Free T3: 2.1 pmol/L (normal range: 3.5-6.5 pmol/L) The patient has no history of thyroid disease. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.label: C
options.text: Start propylthiouracil to treat subclinical hyperthyroidism

options.label: D
options.text: No specific thyroid treatment; continue to manage underlying sepsis with TFT monitoring.

questions.correct_answer: D. No specific thyroid treatment; continue to manage underlying sepsis with TFT monitoring.
questions.explanation:
Sick Euthyroid Syndrome

Definition

Abnormal thyroid function tests in critically ill patients without underlying thyroid disease

Common Causes

- Severe illness (e.g., sepsis, myocardial infarction)

- Major surgery

- Trauma

- Starvation

Typical Laboratory Findings

- Low free T3 (most common)

- Normal free T4

- Normal TSH

Pathophysiology

- Decreased peripheral conversion of T4 to T3

- Increased reverse T3 (rT3)
